title: Machine Learning in the Statistical Natural Language Processing Group of the University of Stuttgart

author: Alexander Fraser, Institute for Natural Language Processing, University of Stuttgart

segmentation: About some work in my group at the University of Stuttgart, we work on multi lingual processing which was aimed at acquiring the training data to solve translation tasks.
So I think most people are aware that Google Translate is a is implemented as a structure prediction problem.
It's supervised learning on very very noisy training data and I'm going to talk a little bit about different kinds of work that can be used to acquire better data.
So.
The first slide is this problem of transliteration mining.
So we just saw a few presentations ago.
The Interlingual links in Wikipedia.
It turns out that using unsupervised learning we can learn very good models of transliteration directly from this graph structure.
So if you look at the examples up there, you have English and Hindi, the English.
Some of the English words are transliterations of the Hindi, which are nicely.
Phonetic Lee written out for you to the right and the goal of this task is simply to automatically separate the ones that are transliterations from those that are not.
Next
We've also been doing a lot of work on new models of translation.
So many of you may be aware that Google Translate uses sequence prediction, but there are now two schools of translation models, sequence based models, and hierarchical models.
The problem we've been working on is the problem of longdistance reordering.
This is the problem that, for instance, the clausal structure of German is very different from the clausal structure of English.
And we're using classification based approaches to do this, and integrating these into machine translation decoders.

So for sequence based translation, we've been switched from the so-called phrase based empty, which involves memorizing chunks of words to Markov models over smaller units and work on synchronous context free grammar decoders.
We've been looking at how to better define the models used to do long distance reordering.
Next
And so two other things that I'm going to that are on the slide that I didn't talk about.
One is distributively ranking for syntactic parsing, which is morphologically aware and the other one is predicting the morphology of German when translating from English to German.
This work is also applicable to French, Spanish and hopefully in the future to Slavic languages which are even richer and morphology.
And so if you'd like to see some more details on this, please come and see our poster.
And I'd like to thank Pascal as well, because it's been very helpful to my group.
